arm_group.description: Patients in this arm of the study will receive oral acetaminophen and an IV placebo
Patients in this arm of the study will receive IV acetaminophen and an oral placebo

brief_summary.textblock:
Both intravenous and oral acetaminophen have been shown to reduce post-operative pain scores
      when given preoperatively. This study investigates if there is a difference between the
      intravenous and the oral forms when given preoperatively to patients undergoing lumbar
      microdiscectomy. We hypothesize that the intravenous formulation does not improve pain
      scores or decrease opioid consumption during the first postoperative day compared to the
      oral formulation.

clinical_study.brief_title: Prospective, Randomized, Double Blind Study Comparing IV vs PO Acetaminophen in Patients Undergoing Lumbar Discectomy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Single level lumbar micro disk surgery

          -  Ages 18-65

        Exclusion Criteria

          -  morbid obesity

          -  prior back surgery

          -  opioid tolerance

          -  pregnancy

intervention.description: 1000 milligrams of intravenous acetaminophen given before surgery

clinical_study.keyword: acetaminophen intravenous oral pain scores opioids
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Compare the Effects of Intravenous Versus Oral Acetaminophen on Postoperative Clinical Outcomes After Ambulatory Lumbar Discectomy

primary_outcome.description: Pain scores are measured using a visual analog scale with patient at rest and also with movement of the lower extremities at four separate times following surgery.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: All doses of opioids given on the day of surgery will be recorded.
secondary_outcome.measure: Quantity of intraoperative and postoperative opioids administered.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment
